items.title: Lemony Lentils and Rice With Caramelized Onions
path: Lemony Lentils and Rice With Caramelized Onions

items.title: Ingredients
items.text: QTY Ingredient ½ cup raisins 1 lemon 4 medium onions ¼ cup plus 3 Tbsp. extra-virgin olive oil, divided ½ tsp sugar 1 cup French green lentils 1 cup basmati rice ¼ tsp ground cinnamon 2 ¼ tsp ground coriander, divided 2 ¼ tsp ground cumin, divided ½ cup fried shallots, divided ½ cup parsley leaves with tender stems ½ cup plain Greek yogurt
path: Lemony Lentils and Rice With Caramelized Onions

items.title: Method
path: Lemony Lentils and Rice With Caramelized Onions

items.title: Lentils
path: Lemony Lentils and Rice With Caramelized Onions

items.title: Rice
items.text:
1. Place 1 cup basmati rice in a medium bowl, cover with cold water, swish rice with your hand, then dump out the water in a swift, fluid motion (the rice will stay at the bottom of the bowl!). Repeat twice. Set rice aside to drain in a fine-mesh sieve.
  2. Heat 2 Tbsp. extra-virgin olive oil in a pot over medium-high until hot. Add ¼ tsp. ground cinnamon, 2 tsp. ground coriander, and 2 tsp. ground cumin and cook, stirring, until fragrant and a shade darker, about 30 seconds.
  3. Add rice and 2 tsp. Diamond Crystal or 1¼ tsp. Morton salt and stir to coat the rice in the spices, about 30 seconds.
  4. Pour in 1½ cups water and bring to a boil (it might happen almost immediately!). Reduce heat to lowest setting, and cover pot. Cook, undisturbed, until water is absorbed, about 15 minutes. Fluff with a fork and cover pot again.
path: Lemony Lentils and Rice With Caramelized Onions

items.title: Onions
items.text:
1. Bring a large pot of generously salted water to a boil. Meanwhile, place ½ cup raisins in a small bowl. Squeeze in juice from one half of lemon and pour 1 Tbsp. very hot water over. This will plump them up. Stir to combine; set aside until ready to use.
  2. Halve and peel 4 medium onions. Go ahead and suit up with some protective eyewear, if that’s necessary for you. Thinly slice onions into half-moons (you should have about 7 cups). This is a fair amount of slicing, but it’s almost the only knifework.
  3. Caramelize the onions: Heat ¼ cup extra-virgin olive oil in a large skillet over medium. Add onions and stir to coat in oil. Season with salt, then reduce heat to low and cover skillet (use a baking sheet if you don’t have a lid). Cook, stirring occasionally, until onions are softened and translucent, about 15 minutes. In this step, the onions steam in the liquid they release, which ensures that they'll caramelize more evenly, with less chance of burning.
  4. Uncover skillet and sprinkle onions with ½ tsp. sugar, which increases caramelization. Increase heat to medium-high and continue to cook onions, stirring frequently and reducing heat as needed, and adding 1 Tbsp. water to deglaze pan (that is, scrape up all those brown bits) if it’s getting too dry, until chocolatey-brown and reduced in size by about two-thirds, 35–40 minutes.
  5. Meanwhile, add 1 cup French green lentils to boiling salted water. Stir so there are no sinkers or stickers, then cook, stirring occasionally, until cooked through but still al dente, 20–25 minutes. Drain and set aside. Wipe pot dry.
  6. As lentils cook, rinse the rice. The easiest way to do this is to place 1 cup basmati rice in a medium bowl, cover with cold water, swish rice with your hand, then dump out the water in a swift, fluid motion (the rice will stay at the bottom of the bowl!). Repeat twice. Set rice aside to drain in a fine-mesh sieve.
  7. Heat 2 Tbsp. extra-virgin olive oil in same pot over medium-high until hot. Add ¼ tsp. ground cinnamon, 2 tsp. ground coriander, and 2 tsp. ground cumin and cook, stirring, until fragrant and a shade darker, about 30 seconds.
  8. Add rice and 2 tsp. Diamond Crystal or 1¼ tsp. Morton salt and stir to coat the rice in the spices, about 30 seconds. Pour in 1½ cups water and bring to a boil (it might happen almost immediately!). Reduce heat to lowest setting, cover with lentils in an even layer, and cover pot. Cook, undisturbed, until water is absorbed, about 15 minutes. Fluff with a fork and cover pot again.
  9. Your onions should be caramelized by now! Add raisins (and any liquid in bowl) and stir to combine. Transfer onion mixture to pot with rice. Add half of fried shallots and juice from remaining lemon half. Stir to combine, season with salt, and keep covered until ready to use.
  10. Now the finishing touches. Coarsely chop ½ cup parsley leaves with tender stems. Mix ½ cup plain Greek yogurt and remaining 1 Tbsp. extra-virgin olive oil, ¼ tsp. coriander, and ¼ tsp. cumin in a small bowl. Season with salt and pepper.
  11. Transfer mujadara to a platter. Top with parsley and remaining fried shallots. Serve with yogurt sauce alongside.

Bon Appetit [[Breakfast]] [[Mains]]

items.text:

  2. Add 1 ¼ cups dry lentils and cook until just tender. The size of lentil will determine cooking time. Little black lentils take 20-30 minutes. 
  3. Strain

items.title: Ingredients
items.text: QTY Desc 1 cup buttermilk, chilled 225g unsalted butter, cut into ½-inch cubes and chilled 525g all-purpose flour 4 tsp baking powder ½ tsp fine sea salt 250ml heavy cream, chilled, plus ¼ cup more for brushing biscuits

items.title: Method
items.text:
1. Preheat the oven to 230°C. Line two baking sheets with parchment paper.
  2. Freeze the buttermilk and butter for 15 minutes.
  3. Place the flour, baking powder, and salt in the bowl of a stand mixer fit with the paddle attachment and mix at low speed until combined, about 30 seconds.
  4. Add in half of the butter, a few pieces at a time, and continue mixing at low speed until the mixture looks sandy and no distinct pieces of butter are visible, about 8 minutes.
  5. Add the rest of the butter and continue mixing until the butter pieces are the size of large peas, about 4 minutes.
  6. Transfer the mixture to a large, wide bowl and very briefly use your fingers to flatten the largest butter piece.
  7. Create a well in the center of the mixture. Pour ¾ cup buttermilk and 1 cup cream into the well. Mix with a rubber spatula using broad, circular strokes.
  8. Add up to ¼ cup more buttermilk as needed to bring dough roughly together (it's fine if the dough remains shagey)
  9. Lightly flour the counter and turn the dough out of the bowl. Gently pat the dough out into a 2 cm -thick rectangle, about 20 cm by 30 cm.
  10. Fold the dough in half, then fold it again, then fold it a third time, then use a rolling pin to gently roll the dough back out to a 2 cm thick rectangle, about 20 cm by 30 cm.
  11. Lightly flour the counter and roll the dough to a height of about 3 cm
  12. Cut straight down with a 6 cm biscuit cutter, wiping and flouring the cutter between each cut. This will ensure the biscuits rise straight up, instead of sloping over.
  13. Reroll the scraps once and cut remaining dough into biscuits.
  14. Place the biscuits about ½ inch apart on the prepared baking sheets and brush the tops generously with cream.
  15. Bake for 8 minutes, then rotate pans and switch their oven positions.
  16. Continue baking another 8 to 10 minutes, until the biscuits are golden brown and feel light when picked up.
  17. Transfer biscuits to a wire rack and cool for 5 minutes. Serve warm.

items.title: To freeze
items.text:
the biscuits for up to 6 weeks, freeze cut biscuits in a single layer on a baking sheet until solid then transfer to plastic freezer bag and freeze. To bake, do not defrost. Brush frozen biscuits with cream and bake for 1o minutes at 450 F and io to 12 minutes at 375°F.

items.title: Base
items.text: QTY Ing 200g shortbread or digestive biscuits 100g unsalted butter 1 tbsp golden syrub

items.title: Filling
items.text: QTY Ing 100g milk chocolate, chopped 100g dark chocolate, chopped, (plus extra shaved chocolate to garnish) 1 tsp vanilla extract 2 tbsp pure icing sugar, sifted 200ml thickened cream, plus extra to serve . Cocoa powder, to garnish

items.title: Base
items.text:
1. Place the biscuits in a food processor and pulse to form fine crumbs.
  2. Place the butter and golden syrup in a saucepan over low heat, stirring, until butter melts
  3. Pour into processor and pulse to combine.
  4. Press the biscuit mixture into the base and sides of six 10cm loose-bottomed tart pans. Chill until required.

items.title: Filling
items.text:
1. Melt the milk and dark chocolate together in a heatproof bowl over a saucepan of simmering water (don't let the bowl touch the water).
  2. Remove from heat, stir until smooth, then allow to cool for 5 minutes.
  3. Stir in the vanilla and fold in the icing sugar .
  4. Whip cream until soft peaks form, then fold into the chocolate mixture.
  5. Pour into the tart pans and chill for at least 2 hours until the chocolate filling is set.

items.title: To Serve
items.text:
Drizzle the plates with melted chocolate, top tarts with extra whipped cream and sprinkle with shaved chocolate and cocoa powder . Serve with strawberries .

Taste

items.title: Method
items.text:
1. Combine everything into a microwave safe bowl and microwave in 20 seconds increments, stirring after increment until melted. Allow it to cool a little.
  2. Pour it over everything you like, or use it to coat frozen fruits and other treats.

items.title: Ingredients
items.text: QTY Ing 3/4 cup  milk 1 tbsp  maple syrup or honey 1 tsp  pure vanilla extract 3 tbsp chia seeds

items.title: Method
items.text:
1. In any glass container with a tight seal lid, add ingredients in the following order: milk, maple syrup, vanilla and chia seeds. If you would like to add toppings in the morning, use bigger jars, otherwise use smaller jars (pictured).
  2. Stir well with a spoon or fork, let sit for 1 minute and stir 2 more times. This will prevent lumps. 
  3. Then refrigerate overnight.
  4. When ready to eat, stir well and top with favourite toppings: nuts, berries, fruit, coconut flakes etc.

items.title: Overnight Oats
items.text:
Yield: Serves 4

Prep Time: 5 minutes

items.title: Ingredients
items.text: QTY Desc 2 cups old-fashioned rolled oats 2 cups dairy milk or unsweetened non-dairy milk 1 cup plain Greek or non-dairy yogurt 3 tablespoons maple syrup or honey 1 tablespoon chia seeds (optional) 1/4 teaspoon ground cinnamon 1/4 teaspoon kosher salt . Optional toppings: fruits, nuts, seeds, nut butter

items.title: Method
items.text:
1. Add ingredients to a large bowl. Place all the ingredients in a large bowl.
  2. Stir together. Stir together until well combined.
  3. Cover and refrigerate overnight. You can divide the oats into individual jars at this point if desired. Cover and refrigerate for at least 4 hours, preferably overnight.
  4. Stir before serving. Stir again before serving with desired toppings.

items.title: Pork Belly Popcorn
items.text: ![[0A6AE2CA-C5E1-4B58-BA4F-B22E2CC978FD.jpeg]] Serves 4

items.title: Ingredients
items.text: 750g Pilton Valley Premium Pork belly, skin removed and cut into 2-3cm squares ½ cup cornflour 2 teaspoons smoked paprika 2 teaspoons ground cumin 2 teaspoons sea salt flakes ½ teaspoon finely ground white pepper ¼ teaspoon finely ground black pepper vegetable oil, for deep frying lemon wedges and chilli sauce, to serve

items.title: Method
items.text:
1. Combine cornflour, paprika, cumin, coriander, sea salt, white pepper and black pepper in a bowl. Add Pilton Valley Premium Pork belly to spice mixture and toss until lightly coated.
  2. Heat oil in a saucepan over medium heat. Deep-fry pork in batches for 4-5 minutes or until golden and crisp. Transfer to a tray lined with paper towel and keep warm. Repeat with remaining pork.
  3. Serve pork with lemon wedges and chilli sauce.

Pilton Valley Pork

[[Mains]]

items.title: Ingredients
items.text: QTY Desc 1 tablespoon extra virgin olive oil 1 cup (90g) finely shredded Chinese cabbage (wombok) 1 tablespoon oyster sauce 200g pork mince 1 eggwhite 1 tbsp hoisin sauce 2 teaspoons finely grated ginger 24 gow gee wrappers (dumpling pastry)

items.title: Method
items.text:
1. Place the oil in a large non-stick frying pan over medium heat.
  2. Add the cabbage and cook, stirring with a wooden spoon, for 5 minutes or until the cabbage is soft.
  3. Add the oyster sauce, stir and set aside to cool.
  4. Place the pork, eggwhite, hoisin and ginger in a big bowl. Add the cooled cabbage and mix well to combine.
  5. Place 6 of the gow gee wrappers on a clean, dry surface and, using a pastry brush, brush the edges with a little water.
  6. Place 2 teaspoons of the pork mixture in the centre of each wrapper. Fold the edges over, pressing with your fingertips, to seal.
  7. Repeat to make 24 dumplings.
  8. Using scissors, cut a round of non-stick baking paper to fit the base of a large bamboo steamer. Fold the paper in half 4 times to make a narrow triangle. Snip some tiny triangles along the folded edge. Open the paper and there should be lots of little holes for letting steam through.
  9. Place the paper in the steamer with 12 of the dumplings on top. Cover with the lid and carefully place the steamer over a large saucepan of rapidly simmering water. Steam for 8-10 minutes or until the pork is cooked through. STEP 5 Wearing oven gloves (steam is super hot), carefully remove the dumplings from the steamer with tongs and keep them warm. Repeat with the remaining dumplings. Serve with some soy and chilli sauce for dipping. MAKES 24

Unknown

[[Mains]]

items.title: Ingredients
items.text: 1 kg Pilton Valley Premium Pork mince 1 medium red onion, grated 1 large carrot, peeled and grated 1 cup panko breadcrumbs 2 tablespoons tomato sauce 2 tablespoons barbecue sauce 1 large zucchini 1/3 cup plain flour 1 tablespoon olive oil ¾ cup grated 4 cheese melt or mozzarella cheese Chopped cherry tomatoes, oven fries and tomato sauce, to serve

items.title: Method
items.text:
1. Preheat oven to 200°C/180°C fan-forced. Line a large baking tray with baking paper.
  2. Place Pilton Valley Premium Pork mince, onion, carrot, breadcrumbs, tomato sauce and barbecue sauce into a large bowl. Grate zucchini and firmly squeeze in your hands to remove liquid. Add zucchini to pork mixture. Stir until combined. Season with salt and pepper. Roll mixture into 12 large round rissoles. Lightly coat rissoles with flour and place on a tray.
  3. Heat oil in a large frying pan over medium heat. Cook rissoles, turning often, for 8-10 minutes or until evenly browned. Transfer to prepared baking tray. Bake for 10 minutes or until cooked through.
  4. Sprinkle rissoles with grated cheese. Bake for 5 minutes or until cheese has melted. Serve rissoles with tomatoes, oven-fries and tomato sauce.

Pilton Valley Pork

[[Mains]]

items.title: Ingredients
items.text: QTY Description 360g cake flour 1 tsp baking soda 10g unsweetened natural cocoa powder 1/2 tsp salt 113g unsalted butter, softened to room temperature 400g granulated sugar 240ml canola or vegetable oil 4 large eggs, room temperature and separated 1 tbsp pure vanilla extract 1 tsp distilled white vinegar - liquid or gel red food coloring 240ml buttermilk, at room temperature

items.title: Method
items.text:
1. Preheat oven to 350°F (177°C). Grease two 9-inch cake pans, line with parchment paper rounds, then grease the parchment paper. Parchment paper helps the cakes seamlessly release from the pans. (If it’s helpful, see this parchment paper rounds for cakes video & post.)
  2. Make the cake: Whisk the flour, baking soda, cocoa powder, and salt together in a large bowl. Set aside.
  3. Using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the butter and sugar together on medium-high speed until combined, about 1 minute. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl with a rubber spatula as needed. Add the oil, egg yolks, vanilla extract, and vinegar and beat on high for 2 minutes. (Set the egg whites aside.) Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl with a silicone spatula as needed.
  4. With the mixer on low speed, add the dry ingredients in 2-3 additions alternating with the buttermilk. Beat in your desired amount of food coloring just until combined. I use 1-2 teaspoons gel food coloring. Vigorously whisk or beat the 4 egg whites on high speed until fluffy peaks form as pictured above, about 3 minutes. Gently fold into cake batter. The batter will be silky and slightly thick.
  5. Divide batter between cake pans. Bake for 30-32 minutes or until the tops of the cakes spring back when gently touched and a toothpick inserted in the center comes out clean. If the cakes need a little longer as determined by wet crumbs on the toothpick, bake for longer. However, careful not to overbake as the cakes may dry out. Remove cakes from the oven and cool completely in the pans set on a wire rack. The cakes must be completely cool before frosting and assembling.

Sally's Baking Addiction [[Baking]]

items.title: Salsa Verda
items.text:
1 medium shallot, finely diced 3 tbsp red wine vinegar 1/4 cup finely chopped parsley leaves 1/4 cup extra virgin olive oil salt

Salt Fat Acid Heat [[Ingredients]]

items.title: Ingredients
items.text: QTY Desc 140g unsalted butter, very soft + more for greasing  55g browned butter ¾ tsp kosher salt  140g toasted sugar 270g plain flour 55g corn flour

items.title: Method
items.text:
1. Brush a 6 x 10 (1/8 sheet) rimmed baking sheet with a light coating of soft butter. Add 1-2 tablespoons of demerara sugar and tilt the pan until it is well coated.
  2. Preheat the oven to 150 °C.
  3. Combine butter, browned butter, salt, and toasted sugar in the bowl of a stand mixer. Mix well for 2-3 minutes. 
  4. Meanwhile, combine the flour and cornstarch in a bowl. Whisk well to combine. 
  5. Add half of the dry ingredients and continue mixing the ingredients for 30 seconds. Then add the remaining dry ingredients and mix until a crumbly dough forms. 
  6. Transfer the dough to the prepared pan and gently press it into the sides and corners of the tray.
  7. Top the shortbread with a generous sprinkling of more demerara sugar.
  8. Bake for 1 - 1.5 hours  or until the top is set and has become lightly golden. 
  9. Allow the shortbread to cool for 10-15 minutes
  10. While still warm, cut the cookies to the desired size using a thin knife. 

  11. Allow the cookies to cool in the pan for a minimum of 4 hours or up to overnight.

  12. Once the cookies are completely cooled, serve with your choice of warm beverage or cover in plastic wrap. The cookies can be kept at room temperature for up to 2 days.

Binging With Babish

items.title: Method
items.text:
1. Preheat oven to 180°C.
  2. Place the mozzarella, 1 cup (80g) of the parmesan, the ricotta and milk in a large bowl and mix to combine. Set aside.
  3. Line the base of a lightly greased 20cm x 30cm ovenproof dish with a layer of lasagne sheets, trimming to fit.
  4. Top with one-third of the beef and a second layer of lasagne sheets. Top with one-third of the cheese mixture.
  5. Repeat the layering twice more using the remaining lasagne sheets, beef and cheese mixture.
  6. Sprinkle the top layer of cheese mixture with the remaining parmesan and drizzle with the oil.
  7. Place the dish on an oven tray and bake for 35-40 minutes or until golden brown and cooked through

[[Baking]]

items.title: Ingredients
items.text: QTY Ingredient 201 g  plain flour 24 g  caster sugar 2.4 tsp  baking powder 198 ml  milk , full fat, slightly warmed 90g unsalted butter , melted and slightly cooled 2  large eggs , at room temperature ½ tsp vanilla essence - Pinch cooking / kosher salt

items.title: Method
items.text:
1. Whisk dry - Place the flour, sugar, baking powder and salt in a large mixing bowl. Whisk to mix.
  2. Whisk in wet - Add milk, eggs and vanilla. Whisk to combine. Add melted butter then whisk until lump free. The batter should be pourable but thick - slightly thinner than pancakes.
  3. Recommended resting Cover then refrigerate overnight, or for at least 2 hours. Softer insides, better flavour. Else, proceed immediately with cooking.
  4. Preheat a waffle maker. A non stick one will not need oil, plus there is butter in the batter.
  5. Cooking - Use a ladle to pour batter in to just cover the iron. Don't get greedy - it will leak out the sides! Cook until golden and crisp - my good waffle iron takes 3 1/2 minutes, my Kmart one takes 6 minutes.
  6. Serving - Transfer onto plates and serve as you go, with desired toppings. Or, put on a rack and keep warm in a preheated 70°C/150°F oven while you continue cooking!

Recipe Tin Eats [[Breakfast]]

items.title: Ingredients
items.text: QTY Desc 350g plain flour 2tsp cream of tartar 1tsp bicarbonate soda ½ tsp salt 300g granulated sugar 220g unsalted butter 2 large eggs 2tsp pure vanilla extract

items.title: Method
items.text:
To make the snickerdoodle dough grab a bowl and mix together the cream of tartar, salt, bicarbonate of soda and flour until well combined.

In a separate larger bowl beat together the sugar and butter with an electric whisk until light and fluffy. Add in the eggs and vanilla extract and whizz away until just combined.

Now add the dry ingredients to the beaten egg mixture, adding slowly in about 4-5 batches. The mixture will thicken as you go, keep whisking until just combined and smooth.

To make the cinnamon sugar, mix together the 2tbsp cinnamon and 50g sugar in a bowl and leave to one side.

Going back to the batter, grab an ice cream scoop and scoop up the dough, roll a ball with your hands of the dough and then place in the cinnamon sugar. Once coated all over place on a lined baking tray spread apart. Repeat with all the dough using extra lined trays as necessary.

Bake for 10minutes in an oven pre-heated to 180fan/200c/400f trying to just get the outer edges firmed and the middle looking a little softer, cracks are fine though, allow to cool fully before eating.

Barry Lewis

[[Baking]]

items.title: Ingredients
items.text: QTY Desc 1 cup chickpea flour (4 1/2 ounces) 1 cup water 1 1/2 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil, plus more for the pan and drizzling 1/2 teaspoon kosher salt 1 teaspoon za'atar (optional)

items.title: Method
items.text:
1. Prepare the chickpea batter. Whisk the chickpea flour, water, olive oil, and salt together in a medium bowl until smooth. Let rest for 30 minutes to give the flour time to absorb the water
  2. Preheat the oven and then the pan. Arrange an oven rack 6 inches below the broiler element and heat to 450°F. About 5 minutes before the batter is done resting, place a 10-inch cast iron skillet in the oven and turn the oven to broil.
  3. Add the batter to the prepared pan. Carefully remove the hot skillet from the oven. Add about 1 teaspoon of oil, enough to coat the bottom of the pan when the pan is swirled. Pour the batter into the center of the pan. Tilt the pan so the batter coats the entire surface of the pan, if needed.
  4. Broil the socca for 5 to 8 minutes. Broil until you see the top of the socca begin to blister and brown, 5 to 8 minutes. The socca should be fairly flexible in the middle but crispy on the edges. If the top is browning too quickly before the batter is fully set, move the skillet to a lower oven rack until done.
  5. Slice and serve. Use a flat spatula to work your way under the socca and ease it from the pan onto a cutting board. Slice it into wedges or squares, sprinkle with salt and pepper, and drizzle with more olive oil and sprinkle with the za'atar if using.

The Kitchn [[Baking]] [[Sides]]

[[Baking]]

items.title: Ingredients
items.text:
MAKES 8

QTY Desc 175g white spelt flour 1 tbsp baking powder 55g caster (superfine) sugar 1 egg 250ml milk 1 tsp vanilla extract (my secret trick) 40g unsalted butter, melted

items.title: Method
items.text:
1. Place the flour, baking powder and sugar in a big bowl and mix to combine, using a whisk.
  2. Break the egg into a medium jug. Add the milk, vanilla and melted butter and whisk to combine.
  3. Using a spoon, dig a well in the centre of the flour mixture. Pour the egg mixture into the well, then whisk it all together to make a smooth batter.
  4. Heat a large, lightly greased non-stick fryingpan over medium heat. Using a ladle or a cup, add about ¼ cup (60ml) of the batter to the pan for each pancake. Cook pancakes for 1-2 minutes each side or until they re golden, using a turner to flip them.
  5. Stack and serve the pancakes warm from the pan with some natural yoghurt, maple syrup and berries (or your own favourite toppings).

Donna Hay

[[Breakfast]]

items.title: Ingredients
items.text: QTY Ing 3 tbsp  ghee 1 large onion, diced 4 cloves garlic, rough chopped 2 tbsp ginger, finely chopped ½ tsp  fennel seeds 1 tsp black mustard seeds 2 tsp  cumin seeds 2 tsp  garam masala 400g baby spinach (fresh or frozen) 20 fresh mint leaves ½ cup plain yogurt (or vegan yogurt) 3–4  cups  cooked black lentils or French green lentils 1 tsp salt

items.title: Method
items.text: [[Lentils]]

items.title: Dahl
items.text:
1. Make the Spinach Sauce: Sautee the onion in ghee, in a large pan, over medium heat for 3-4 minutes
  2. Add garlic, ginger and chilies. Saute until fragrant and golden.
  3. Add the fennel seeds, mustard seeds, cumin seeds and garam masala and stir two minutes.
  4. Lower heat to low. Add the fresh spinach, fresh mint, fenugreek and 2 tablespoons water. Cover pan, 2-3 minutes, letting spinach wilt. Give a few stirs. Don’t overcook!
  5. Blend Spinach Sauce: Place the wilted spinach mixture in a blender and add the 3/4 cups of water. Pulse and few times (hold the lid down tight). If you want a smooth sauce, blend until smooth.
  6. Pour it back into the pan, set on low heat. Don’t overheat or you will lose the pretty color.
  7. Combine: Stir in the yogurt, lentils and salt. You want this slightly more salty because you are serving over rice which will mellow it out a lot. For more heat add a pinch of cayenne or chili flakes.  If you want a little acidity a tiny squeeze of lemon is nice.
  8. Serve with the basmati rice and naan bread

Emerald Dal will keep up to 4 days in the fridge.

Sorted

[[Mains]]

items.title: Ingredients
items.text:
Makes 12 regular cupcakes

QTY Desc 225g caster sugar 210g self-raising flour, sifted 1 tsp baking powder 25g cornflour 125g fresh, ripe strawberries, hulled and crushed 225g unsalted butter, at room temperature 4 large eggs, free-range or organic

items.title: Method
items.text:
Preheat the oven to 160°C (fan) /180°C/350°F/gas mark 4 and line a

12-hole muffin tray with the appropriate size cupcake cases.

Put the sugar, flour, baking powder, cornflour and crushed strawberries into a food processor. Pulse until evenly mixed (roughly 4 seconds). Add the butter and eggs and process briefly until even (roughly 10 seconds). If you are using an electric hand mixer, cream the butter and sugar together first, beat in the eggs, one by one, and then add the remaining ingredients and beat well together.

Carefully spoon the mixture into the cupcake cases, filling them to about two-thirds full. Bake in the oven for about 25 minutes. The cakes will be fairly moist even when cooked.

Remove from the oven and leave the cakes in their tins for about 10 minutes before carefully placing on a wire rack to cool.

Once they are completely cool, carefully make a small hole in the centre of each cupcake and use a teaspoon to push the strawberry jam into the hole - you can slightly warm the jam in a saucepan first to soften it before pushing it into the sponge.

Wash the 12 strawberries and allow them to dry off on kitchen paper to limit any excess water and juice spoiling the buttercream once they are on the cupcakes. Decorate the cupcakes with vanilla buttercream icing and, just before serving, place a fresh strawberry in the centre.

Unkown [[Baking]]

items.title: Ingredients
items.text: QTY Ingredient 6  large egg whites (approximately 230g) 400g  granulated sugar 350g  unsalted butter, softened but still cool and cut into tbsp size pieces 2 tsp  pure vanilla extract 1/8 tsp  salt

items.title: Method
items.text:
1. Make sure all the tools you are using are completely cleaned, dried, and grease-free. A quick wipe with a little lemon juice or white vinegar is very helpful.
  2. Separate the eggs: If you haven’t done so yet, separate the eggs first. Separate 1 egg white in a small bowl, then place the egg white in your heatproof mixing bowl. Repeat with the remaining egg whites. This way, if a yolk breaks in one of them, you don’t waste the whole batch.
  3. Whisk sugar into the egg whites, then set the bowl over a saucepan filled with just two inches of simmering water over medium heat. Do not let the bottom of the egg whites bowl touch the water. Whisk the whites and sugar constantly until sugar is dissolved and mixture has thinned out, about 4 minutes. The mixture will be thick and tacky at first, then thin out and be frothy white on top. To test that it’s ready, you can use your finger or an instant read thermometer. Lightly and quickly dip your finger (it’s very hot, be careful) and rub the mixture between your thumb and finger. You shouldn’t feel any sugar granules. If using a thermometer, the temperature should read 71°C.
  4. No need to let it cool down to start this next step– it’s important to begin mixing while it is still warm. Transfer mixture to the bowl of a stand mixer fitted with a whisk attachment. On medium-high speed, beat the mixture until stiff glossy peaks form and the meringue is no longer warm to the touch, at least 10-15 minutes. On particularly humid days, this has taken me up to 17-18 minutes. If it’s still not reaching stiff peaks, stop the mixer, place the bowl–uncovered–in the refrigerator for 10 minutes, then return to the mixer and continue beating until stiff peaks form. (This has always worked for me when it’s taking forever to reach stiff peaks.)
  5. If the bowl and meringue still feel warm, wait until both cool to room temperature (21°C) before adding the butter in the next step. Feel free to place it in the refrigerator. A warm bowl and meringue will melt the butter.
  6. Switch the stand mixer to the paddle attachment. On medium-high speed, add the butter 1 Tablespoon at a time. Wait for the butter to fully mix in before adding the next Tablespoon. After all the butter has been added, turn the mixer down to medium speed and fully beat in the vanilla and salt, about 30 seconds.
  7. Your Swiss meringue buttercream should be thick, creamy, and silky smooth and is ready to use on any cake, cupcake, or other confection.

Sally's Baking Addiction

[[Baking]] [[Ingredients]]

items.title: Tempering Chocolate
items.text:
Stage Temp Heat 46°C Cool 27°C Reheat 31°C

Unknown [[Ingredients]]

items.title: Ingredients
items.text: QTY Desc 1.8kg white sugar

items.title: Method
items.text:
1. Adjust oven rack to center position and preheat oven to 150°C.
  2. Pour sugar into a 9- by 13-inch glass or ceramic baking dish.
  3. Toast until the sugar turns ivory, about 1 hour.
  4. Stir thoroughly and continue roasting, pausing to stir every 30 minutes. The sugar will produce steam as a byproduct of toasting, so it must be stirred well to allow that moisture to escape. Stirring should also help move hot sugar from the edges toward the center, and cool sugar from the center toward the edges, for even toasting.
  5. Continue toasting and stirring every 30 minutes until the sugar has darkened to the desired degree, from a light beige to the color of traditional brown sugar, between 2 and 4 hours more.
  6. When the sugar has finished toasting, set aside and cool to room temperature, stirring from time to time to speed the process and allow for continued evaporation of steam.
  7. Once fully cool, transfer to an airtight container and store as you would plain white sugar. It can be used interchangeably, by weight or volume, in any recipe that calls for white sugar.

items.title: See Also
items.text:
Science [[Shortbread]]

Serious Eats [[Ingredients]]

items.title: Ingredients
items.text: QTY Ing 700g chicken 1 onion 2 garlic cloves 1/2 cup (200g) yoghurt or milk 3 tbsp  vegetable oil 2 tbsp  tomato paste 1 tsp  freshly ground black pepper 1 tsp  paprika 1 tsp  kosher salt

items.title: Method
items.text:
1. Cut the meat into 1-inch pieces. Set aside.
  2. Using the finest grater possible, grate the onion and garlic cloves over a medium bowl.
  3. Pour the pulp and juice into a fine mesh strainer and, using a wooden spoon, press out the juice into a medium bowl. Discard the onion and garlic pulp; reserve the juice.
  4. Stir together the onion-garlic juice, yogurt, oil, tomato paste, black pepper, paprika, and salt.
  5. Add the cubed chicken and toss to coat.
  6. Cover the bowl and refrigerate it for at least 4 hours, preferably overnight for maximum flavor.
  7. Prepare a medium (175°C to 190°C) gas or charcoal grill fire.
  8. Remove the chicken pieces from the marinade and thread them onto soaked bamboo kebab skewers or metal skewers. The chunks of chicken can touch each other, but don’t put them too close together to ensure they cook through. Discard any remaining marinade.
  9. Sprinkle the kebabs generously with salt and place on pre heated grill. Grill evenly on all sides, about 12 minutes total.
  10. Garnish with sumac, dried oregano, and paprika, if desired, and serve.

The Spruce Eats

[[Mains]]

items.title: Ingredients
items.text: QTY Ingredient 230g  unsalted butter 480-600g icing sugar 60ml heavy cream, half-and-half, or whole milk, at room temperature 2 tsp  pure vanilla extract

items.title: Method
items.text:
1. With a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the butter on medium speed until creamy, about 2 minutes.
  2. Add 4 and 1/2 cups confectioners’ sugar, the heavy cream, and vanilla extract. Beat on low speed for 30 seconds, then increase to medium-high speed and beat for 2 full minutes. Taste. Add a pinch of salt if frosting is too sweet. I always add 1/8 teaspoon.
  3. Adjust if needed: You can control the consistency at this point—add up to 1/2 cup more confectioners’ sugar if frosting is too thin or more heavy cream if frosting is too thick (add only 1 Tablespoon at a time, beat together, then taste and add more if desired).
  4. Use immediately or cover tightly and store for up to 1 week in the refrigerator or up to 3 months in the freezer. After freezing, thaw in the refrigerator then beat the frosting on medium speed for a few seconds so it’s creamy again. After thawing or refrigerating, beating in a splash of heavy cream or milk will help thin the frosting out again, if needed.

items.title: Ingredients
items.text:
QTY Desc 1 ½ cups whole milk 1 ½ cups heavy cream ¾ cup granulated sugar 4 large egg yolks

[[Baking]]

items.title: Ingredients
items.text: QTY Desc ¼ cup + 2 tbsp all-purpose flour 2 tbsp granulated sugar ¼ tsp baking powder ⅛ tsp salt ¼ cup + 2 tbsp milk 1 tbsp vanilla extract 2 tbsp unsalted butter, melted

items.title: Method
items.text:
1. In a medium bowl, whisk together dry ingredients.
  2. In a measuring cup, whisk together milk, vanilla bean paste, and vanilla extract.
  3. Make a well in the center of the dry ingredients then pour the milk mixture into the center, followed by the melted butter.
  4. Whisk until no lumps remain and batter is smooth and well combined.
  5. Pour into a 16-ounce microwave-safe mug.
  6. Microwave on high for 130 seconds or 2 minutes and 10 seconds.
  7. Carefully remove and enjoy!

Table for Two

[[Baking]]

items.title: Ingredients
items.text: QTY Desc 185g unsalted butter, chopped 220g caster (superfine) sugar 1½ teaspoons vanilla extract 375g plain (all-purpose) flour 1 egg 1 egg yolk

items.title: Method
items.text:
1. Place the butter, sugar and vanilla in a food processor and process until smoot
  2. Add the flour, egg and extra egg yolk and process until a smooth dough forms,
  3. Turn the dough out onto a lightly floured surface and divide in half
  4. Roll each piece out between sheets of non-stick baking paper until 5mm thick
  5. Refrigerate for 10 minutes or until firm Preheat oven to 160°C (325°F).
  6. Remove the top sheets of baking paper from the dough. Using a 6cm round cookie cutter, cut shapes from the dough, re-rolling as necessary.
  7. Place the rounds on lightly greased baking trays lined with non-stick baking paper and bake for 12-14 minutes or until golden.
  8. Allow to cool on trays for 10 minutes before transferring onto wire racks to cool.

Donna Hay

[[Baking]]

items.title: Ingredients
items.text: QTY Ing 160g icing sugar 280g smooth peanut butter 80g unsalted butter 1 tsp vanilla extract 80ml single cream

items.title: Method
items.text:
1. Placing icing sugar, peanut butter, butter and vanilla in a mixing bowl
  2. Beat on medium for 4 minuted till well combined
  3. Add the cream and beat for 1 minute until light and fluffy
  4. Spread

items.title: Monday
items.text:
Woke up feeling worse with this cold. Finished the report at work and have taken the rest of the day off. Spent most of the day resting in bed. Had some fun at dinner with the letter chicken nuggets.

Started reading [[Equal Rites]] with Brandon.

items.title: Tuesday 9th July
items.text:
Didn't sleep very well last night. Woke up feeling better then yesterday but quickly felt worse. Spent most of the day on bed watching tv with Benita.

Started reading WeirDo 2 with Bradley.

items.title: Wednesday 10th July
items.text: Back to work for a 9 hr day today! Could have done without the late afternoon meeting. Messed up getting Benita’s dinner miss heard what she wanted and got completely the wrong thing. Started watching Travelers which is off to a strong start.

items.title: Friday 12th July
items.text: Almost recovered, I just need to catch up on my sleep. Nice quiet day at work to finish off the week which was just what I needed. Looking forward to catching up on the housework over the weekend. Started watching One Piece with Brandon which he is enjoying.

items.title: Sunday 14th July
items.text: Spent the morning at Eagleby Park which is quickly becoming our favourite go to park. My first Hungry Jacks burger for lunch (quite nice!). Finally started to properly plan our Melbourne trip.

items.title: Monday 15th July
items.text: Thankfully a quiet day at worked today but still wiped me out by this afternoon. A bitterly cold day that only became bearable this afternoon. The kids half cleaned up inside the car and I half did the outside, so we still have a mess of a car but now at least it's a presentable mess. Exploding Kittens started strong and so far nothing that I wouldn't want the kids to see, not sure why it is rated MA so far. Nice evening with Benita as both boys went to bed easily tonight.

items.title: Thursday 18th July
items.text: Finally a chill day at home. Didn't plan n getting to much done as it is still so cold. Instead spent most of the day watching TV with Benita. Watched Ride the Eagle with lunch which was much better than I was expecting. A very straight forward story that sticks to the basics of the plot but executes everything it does well.

items.title: Saturday 27th July
items.text: Spent the morning getting ready for the park as we decided to go early to have lunch and a play before the party. Running late as usual and the park was supper busy. Had a decent time and the kids had a lot of fun. Picked up pizza on the way home and found out there is going to be a new Turkish place at Holmview. Watched MIB 2 for movie night which still holds up.

items.title: Sunday 28th July
items.text: Got a good run to make it to the Mt Gravatt show just after it opened at 9. First stop was the Lego which Bradley was in love with going around everything twice. Motorbike jumping, dog jumping and the dinosaur ventriloquist show where also highlights. Bradley's absolute favourite thing from the day was getting to go into the "puppy cuddle" arena. He managed very well with most of the dogs asleep and he even got the courage to hold one by the end. Brandon also had a good time with all the poodles. Brandon was a bit disappointed that he couldn't get a show bag (as none of them where very good) but we made up for it with some hot wheel cars and cool badges. All in all a good day and I am glad we went.

items.title: Friday 2nd August
items.text: Quiet day today as Benita was out for most of it looking for plasticine of all things. Who knew it was so hard to get! Andrea has talked with David about me taking over so we are having a meeting next week to discuss. It sounds like the new grads will be under me soon. Brandon lost a tooth today and asked the tooth fairy for a Minecraft bag. Tooth fairy doesn't take request these days but will still leave a note of asked. Bradley is excited about going to the Paw Patrol show tomorrow which is nice.

items.title: Wednesday 7th August
items.text: Another 2 hours of meetings today just when I was hoping for a quieter day. I did have my first meeting with David to start formalising my move into team lead which is exciting. Haven't been able to spend much time with Benita this week with the way everything has unfolded. Received the new in ground basketball hoop today.

items.title: Monday 12th August
items.text: Bradley drew some really gold sea creatures to go in his octopus habitat while I measured out all the ingredients for our cake. Cake was delicious and Brad was an excellent helper. Shame they were so silly for the rest of the day.

items.title: Tuesday 13th August
items.text: Day full of meetings today but at least they were useful ones. Absolutely wrecked by the end of the day as I haven’t been sleep well. It’s good to have rain again, 110 days according to our records since the last descent fall.

items.title: Wednesday 14th August
items.text: Perfect rainy day to stay in bed and watch TV, all the better that I could do it with Benita as we both had the day off. Dropped Brandon's science diorama off managing to keep it dry on the way! I have started looking properly at bathroom places so hopefully we can start on that soon.

items.title: Friday 16th August
items.text: Finally a quiet day at work even if there was a P2. Poor sleep last has left me very tired for today.

items.title: Saturday 17th August
items.text: Excellent lunch with Benita at a Korean pork hock place at Underwood after looking at bathroom vanities. Both kids seemed to have fun with David at the Cars & coffee day he took them too. It was good to see him spend some quality time with them. Met a very friendly dog on my walk this afternoon that wanted to play. I was worried when I saw it coming up the unfenced driveway but it kept its distance and went and found a stick that it dropped for me. After throwing the stick it was happy to go play by itself and went home after I had passed the house. Skipped movie night but still had pizzas as the boys were too tired and silly to make it through a movie. We did finish Exploding Kittens and I finished reading Equal Rites with Brandon.

items.title: Monday 19th August
items.text: Got the chance to hire my first person today. Scary but exciting. Still feeling off but way better than yesterday so I have no idea what was wrong as it doesn’t feel like an illness. Bradley was very excited when he got home because he won at the science fair for his year level and came home with a huge prize bag. It’s a shame Brandon didn’t get anything but it is nice that Bradley got recognised for his hard work.

items.title: Wednesday 21st August
items.text: This felt like the first normal day in a while. Made good progress in a couple of things at work, making progress in my daily watercolour and a relaxing afternoon until I forgot to get anything out for dinner.

items.title: Friday 23rd August
items.text: Brandon enjoyed all his presents, Lego police crime truck, GShock watch, and a stick sculpture thing. He seemed happy to have a quiet morning at home. Spent it building his Lego then we went out to Yatala Pies fans Baskin and Robins for lunch. so full from lunch no one except Bradley ate all their piece of cake. Finished up the day watch Godzilla vs Kong.

items.title: Saturday 24th August
items.text: Productive day kicking off small things around the house. Disappointing trip to the Hyperdome as I couldn’t find any of the toys I was looking for. I did find a Taz dressed as flash which was cool but not enough to buy. Brandon enjoyed his birthday dinner with his grandparents at Grill’d and was happy with the chess Lego set he got. The upside of having another late night is both kids where tired by the time they went to be so Benita and I got to spend some time together for once.

items.title: Sunday 25th August
items.text: Earlier start then I wanted as Bradley woke me up at 7 looking for the iPad (which was already in the lounge room). Another quietly productive day cleaning up the pantry today. Watched Barbie which was as good as I expected it to be. Found some more time tonight after the kids where in bed to help Benita relax this time.

items.title: Monday 26th August
items.text: Did some actual sys admining for a change today. Been a long time since I have had something to sink my teeth into. Was rusty on the PowerShell but made a good start. Had a snake try to break in to my office so made an emergency Bunnings trip to get some snake repellents.

items.title: Tuesday 27th August
items.text:
It has been awhile since I have had a day as relaxing as this. Definitely one of the best birthdays I have had, the only issues being that I have to keep the Baradur set secret as the Gibson’s have already bought it for my 40th and the lamingtons being mouldy.

Benita got me Wall E / Eve and Gandlaf / Balrog Lego and Bradley was very sweet and gave me one of his prizes from the science competition.

items.title: Thursday 29th August
items.text: Made really good progress on planning for Melbourne today, starting to get excited as long as mum stops going in about gelato. Bradley had a great time at the colour run and was very excited when he got home. Finally gave in an ordered a walking pad so hopefully Benita actually uses it. The Looney Tunes walking medal came today which looks just as good as I had hoped.

items.title: Sunday 1st September
items.text:
A quiet Father’s Day this year as Brandon was sick last. Benita cooked croissants for breakfast, Brandon drew me a cool taz / balrog card, and Bradley drew a good portrait of me in his card. Brandon got me a new oven mitt, a wooden chopping board and a pack of coupons. Bradley got me a pen, a bouncy ball, and a travel mug.

Bradley and I had morning tea with dad so we could have the cake that we all cooked yesterday and to give him his Lego space penguin. Had some fun building the Lego Baleog while Benita built the Lego Eve and Bradley helped sort out the pieces and playing the Art of Rally on the switch. All in all a pretty good day.

items.title: Friday 6th September
items.text: Picked up the walking pad today. It was a nice time out with Benita after the craziness of the last few days.

items.title: Industrial Diamonds
items.text: There is now a glut of natural diamonds too large for jewellery because of X-ray machines used in the digging process. They are now too good at finding them. You can buy a diamond-making machine for $200,000 on Alibaba | Ars Technica

items.title: Wednesday 6th November
items.text: Finally started painting the bathroom. Both quicker and more painful than I thought it would be but I’m glad it’s started.

items.title: Sunday 17th November
items.text: Climate change created the Gobi desert in 1000 bce. Was it a forest when the pyramids was built? #research

items.title: Bath
items.text: Finally rang the guy back to get the bath restored. Taking it out on Sunday and dropping it off next Wednesday.

items.title: Aircon
items.text: Getting a quote tomorrow to aircon the theatre room. Going to be an expensive few weeks but worth it in the end.

items.title: Aircon Quote
items.text: Robert came out today, $3500 to do the theatre room which I think is going to be worth it.

items.title: <% tp.date.now("dddd Do MMMM") %>
items.text: <% tp.file.rename(tp.date.now("YYYY-MM-DD dddd")) %>

items.title: Sunday 8th December
items.text: Spent most of the day hiding from the heat. We got the Christmas tree up and started decorating it. Watched The Grinch and Robin Robin. Had our first swim for the summer.

items.title: <% tp.date.now("dddd Do MMMM") %>
items.text: <% tp.file.rename(tp.date.now("YYYY-MM-DD dddd")) %>

items.title: Wednesday 1st January
items.text:
A Sun a Day Keeps the Doctor Away The black hole in this quasar accretes around one solar mass per day onto an existing mass of ∼17 billion solar masses.”

In other words, J0529−4351 is eating the equivalent of a whole Sun every single day. It’s the Gaston of quasars. As a consequence of this insane diet, J0529−4351 is 500 trillion times more luminous than the Sun. Just utterly incomprehensible radiance. https://www.404media.co/the-year-in-abstracts-obese-genomes-and-banana-galaxies-3/

items.title: Sunday 5th January
items.text:
• Everyone slept in late after yesterday
  • Watched Sonic 3 at Victoria Point, 6/10 from me but 10/10 from Brandon!

items.title: Operation Ouch Live Show
items.text: Kids enjoyed the show with it going into great detail on how our intestines work, why we fart, live endoscope demonstration in the mouth and nose and how to deal with embarrassment while telling a story about capturing dinosaur farts. Well put together shown even if it did jump around story wise.

items.title: Van  Gogh's Night Scenes
items.text: Vincent Van Gogh was so accurate at painting the night sky 4 of his paintings have been dated based on astronomical information.

items.title: Laser Propulsion
items.text: The underside of an aircraft is blasted with a laser that superheats the air underneath it, creating a plasma that explodes the air and propels the craft upward.

items.title: Entertainment
items.text: The Bear: I love the way the show holds shots long enough to make you uncomfortable especially in the wider shots when people are talking to each other Silo: For a high concept show the characters are really the stars of the story [[A Waltz for Matilda]]: Finally picked this up again, it took me awhile to recover from all the truma in the first quarter. I hope that it is happier from here but I fear not. Thor Ragnorok: The movie still stands out amount the Marvel movies by having some actual depth to the characters. It is a shame that the warriors three couldn't have been used more. It would have been nice if the next movies could have kept up this momentum instead of throwing it away.

items.title: Around Town
items.text: Movie Night: Cancelled because of "undesirables" nearby. Strange that the police didn't move them on as we where outside the station. Hyperdome Butcher: On to a winner going here, going to try and make it work that I go here fortnightly. Family Dinner: Fish & chips at mum & dads as we hadn't seen them for awhile and we walked past at an opportune time. Family Walk: We all went for a walk up Tawonga Road on a glorious Sunday morning. Brad and I made it to the top, Brandon almost made and Benita ran out of steam half way up. Besides Brad getting scared by the scary dogs a nice morning out.

items.title: Work
items.text:
It was a quiet week as I focused on catching up on clearing out my emails and tidying up my personal notes vault.

Week 28 Mon 10 - Sun 16 Jul 2023

items.title: Entertainment
items.text: Begin Again: The 2013 movie starting Kiera Knightly and Mark Ruffulo contains a 15 yr old Hailee Steinfeld play Ruffulo's daughter in one of her first acting roles.

items.title: Discoveries
items.text:
New Uranus Images: The planets orbit lasts 84 years and due to its unique 90 tilt its nights last 42 years!

New Hominin Species Found: 40 km outside of Johannesburg, South Africa in the Rising Star Cave, at a site known as the Cradle of Humankind cavers have discovered fossils of a new Hominin species, Homo naledi.

In 2013 a team of cavers surveying the chambers of the cave system found an unmaped whole 18 cm wide leading to a new cave, symbols carved into the walls dated the finds to be between 241,000–335,000 years old.

Anthropologist Berger hired an additional team of six women with both scientific and caving experience to excavate the site (using toothpicks and sometimes porcupine quills, among other tools)

Access to the site required going down a chute using a technique known as the Superman's Crawl because most cavers can only manage to squeeze through by extending one arm above the head while holding the other tight against the body. The chute was on average a 12m long and 20 cm wide.

Berger was careful not to claim the fossils found were anactual burial at the time of discovery. However they identified depressions deep in the chambers of the cave system, in which the bodies of H. naledi adults and several young children had been deposited in a fetal position, suggesting that the intent was to bury the dead. Berger concluded that "we feel they've met the litmus test of the most ancient human burials."

Ars Technica

Week 29 Mon 17 - Sun 23 Jul 2023

items.title: Entertainment
items.text:
Edge of Tomorrow: A fantastic film. Spends the perfect amount of time on the science, none, and great acting by Cruise & Blunt. Seeing the emotional journey both characters go on, mostly shown not told really elevate the movie.

Jurassic World: Dominon The sense of awe and wonder captured in the scene where the brachiosaurus walks through the logging camp is a high point the series has not reached since the first movie. Seeing the dinosaurs in the real world amount familiar surrounding would have been a great chance to show how magnificent any large creature is. The whole sub plot with Grant & Sadler is still the weakest part of the film and despite it being good to see them again little would of been lost if they wheren't in it and it would have made for a tighter movie. Still enjoy watching it, especially with Bran.

Late Watch: Found the perfect watch ![[Pasted image 20230724172542.png]]

items.title: Science
items.text:
Ankylosaurus Find: A fully intact Nodosaur, an ankylosaur with a straight tail has been found in a Canadian mine. It is suspected that it died in a river floating down to the sea in a flood before sinking to the ocean floor. This would explain its remarkable preservation as there would be little chance of scavengers attacking it before it sank into the sediment. Excavation from the mine took 14 days before senior technician spent the next 5 and a half years separating rock from the fossil. All in it too 7 hours a day, 7000 hours total to finish this work.

![[Pasted image 20230724163135.png]]

Space Potato: Can you cook a potato by dropping it from space? No, worst case scenario it experiences a max temp of 150c but only for a few minutes, best case it reaches 1500c but for an even shorter period of time leaving the middle room temp by the time it reaches the ground. Either way because of the low temps in the upper atmosphere it spends most of its time at 17c with the re-entry temps lasting for only a brief period at the start.

items.title: Family
items.text:
Health: Benita has had a mild cold but has been holding up ok so far.

Under 8s Day: Bradley made it through the day even though he is starting to get a cold. Sounds like he had a good day and I'm glad he could go.

HQ Upgrades: I have mostly finished the long neglected final part of the surrounding gardens. Brad insisted on helping move the mulch even though I wasn't planning on doing it yet. Hunger got him in the end and he wanted to stop, one wheel barrow load from finished it.

items.title: Work
items.text: P1: Nice full DB outage to start the week. Multiple monitoring failures

items.title: Personal
items.text: Cold Season: I have been hit again this cold season after Benita and Brad got it last week. It hasn't been to bad except for the lack of sleep. Having wedensday off really helped in it being manageable. Cello Workshop: Unfortunatly Bran did not make it despite our best efforts to keep him away from Brad. Thankfully he recovered pretty quick this time with only the two days off school.

items.title: Hobbies
items.text: Wooden Clocktower: Looking for something quieter and less physical I painted and built a little wooden clock tower model. The sparkly blue and brass paints turned out really well with flat red accents. It looks as good as I was hoping so can't wait to do more. Lord of the Rings: Looking for something easy to learn to start to get into the habit of playing again I have picked up my old LotR soundtrack pieces again. It is very satisfying to be able to learn a song so quickly after struggling through some of the Hamilton songs.

items.title: HQ
items.text:
Back Garden: Relieved that the current round of gardening is coming to a close. Connned the kids into helping choose some plants to finish up the garden and conned dad into helping me cut down some trees to close to the house. Hill Grass: Trying some native grasses to cover the hill and help hold it together. Will it work? Will I keep them alive long enough to find out? Who knows, but at least it is a start.

Week 31 Mon 31 - Sun 06 Aug 2023

items.title: Entertainmnet
items.text:
Silo Season 1: This show is so tense with the uncertainty of what is coming next but with the knowledge that it will be earned and that the a pay off is coming. So many small threads that could have been throw away world building details come together nicely in the final episodes. The acting, writing, cinematography and set design all come together beautifully to support the tension at the core of the show.

The Addams Family Musical Comedy: A heartwarming and funny look at the challenges of marriage and navigating how you fit into your family and the world as you grow up. The perfect use of of comedy and the zanieness of the Addams family to look at issues that we all face. The adaption to a musical is well done with how important music is to the original series it provided a natural transition to the songs. A bigger cast than I was expecting with the full Addams family, lurch, unidentified grandmother, Wednesday's fiancée and his parents and on top of all that a background chorus of 8(?) ghosts of Addams family past. All did very well with at time an overwhelming amount of things to look at with everyone committing to their own performances.

Week 32 Mon 7 - Sun 13 Aug 2023

items.title: Entertainment
items.text: The Bear - Season 1:

items.title: HQ
items.text:
Back Garden: I will miss having the tinkering about in the garden that I have been doing in my spare time. It has been a fun little winter project and it is nice to have Brad involved in helping around the house.

Week 33 Mon 14 - Sun 20 Aug 2023

items.title: Entertainment
items.text:
Wylah - Custodians: Did not enjoy reading this, it is not written to be read aloud and with the large cast of characters to keep track of, semi switching between first and third person, and the unpolished writing overshadowed the interesting enough story and different perspective of a First Nation story.

Formula 1: Singapore Wow what a race, from the early VSC to Sainz helping Norris holding of the Mercs to Russell binning it on the last lap a fantastic race.

Zelda Tears of the Kingdom 110 hours in I definitely got my monies worth. The polish and care makes the game transcend the lacklustre story & gameplay into something special. The organic funny moments and endless exploration that is constantly rewarded keeps the game going far beyond what it should on paper. A special time with the kids that I will miss now that it is over.

items.title: Hobbies
items.text:
Heat Pedal to the Metal A simple game with more interesting desicions as it goes on. Can' wait until we can play it again.

Week 38 Mon 18 - Sun 24 Sep 2023

items.title: The Bear
items.text: Like a wish from a genie what happens when you get what you want but not in the way you expected?

items.title: Mind MGMT
items.text: A mystery backed up by fantastic art and story telling.

items.title: The Unbearable Weight of Massive Talent
items.text: So much fun. Cage gives a surprisingly nuanced performance considerering he was essentially playing himself. Manages to stick the landing even as the plot gets increasingly meta.

items.title: Make It So
items.text:
So far a more interesting look at what it was like growing up in the North of England in the 1940's & 50's then the early history of Stewart.

Week 42 Mon 16 - Sun 22 Oct 2023

items.text: <% if (tp.file.title.endsWith(tp.file.folder())) { %> %% Zoottelkeeper: Beginning of the autogenerated index file list %% [[Simmer & Stir/Mains/Dough/images/Index_images|Index_images]] [[Simmer & Stir/Mains/Dough/Sourdough Pizza|Sourdough Pizza]] %% Zoottelkeeper: End of the autogenerated index file list %% <% } %>

items.title: Ingredients
items.text: QTY List 432g White Flour 48g Spelt Flour 322g Water 9g Salt 72g Sourdough Starter

items.title: Method
items.text:
1. In your mixing bowl measure out the called for water minus 50g and add your mature starter; swish around with a whisk or spatula to disperse. Then add in flour, salt, and malt and mix a bit with your hand (so when you turn on your mixer dry flour doesn’t eject out dusting you head to toe). Attach the dough hook to your mixer and turn on speed #2 (for a KitchenAid) and mix for a few minutes until everything comes together. Once it is a single dry mass dribble in the remaining 50g water over the course of a minute or two while mixing, waiting to add more water until the previous liquid is absorbed.
  2. At 75-77°F (23-25°C) ambient temperature, bulk fermentation should go for about 2.5 hours. Perform 3-4 sets of stretch and folds — a North, South, East, and West fold for each set – during the bulk, spaced out by 30 minutes.
  3. After 2.5 hours in bulk, use some olive oil and lightly oil a bowl large enough to hold the dough. Then, dump the dough out onto the counter and using two hands shape the dough into a very tight boule. It’s important here to get the dough nice and taut, don’t worry about degassing.Wrap the bowl with reusable plastic wrap and place in the refrigerator overnight.
  4. Remove the bulk container with the dough from the refrigerator and dump the dough out onto your un-floured bench. Divide the dough into two 290g dough balls and using almost no flour form each into a very tight ball. It’s incredibly important here to create a ball that has a completely closed bottom. You want a tight skin on each of these that completely surrounds the dough ball.
  5. Once the balls are shaped and onto the proof vessel cover with plastic wrap so they do not dry out during proof (this is why a high-walled dish works well, it keeps the wrap off of the dough). The balls will proof on the counter, around 75°F (23°C), for about 6 hours.
  6. Thirty minutes before you plan to bake the first pizza toss your entire proofing vessel with dough into the refrigerator. It’s so, so much easier to shape out the dough when it’s cold from the fridge and I find that there is no need to let the dough warm to room temperature before baking. This is optional but recommended.

The Perfect Loaf

items.title: Multimodal Narrative
items.text: Multimodal narrative to share with their peers. They will plan, draft, and write a story that includes a clear beginning (orientation), middle (complication), and ending (resolution). To enhance their storytelling, students will also incorporate images that complement and support their narrative.

items.title: Agile Overview
items.text: Agile is a structured and iterative approach to project management and product development. It recognizes the volatility of product development, and provides a methodology for self-organizing teams to respond to change without going off the rails.

items.title: Scrum
items.text:
Scrum teams commit to completing an increment of work, which is potentially shippable, through set intervals called sprints. Their goal is to create learning loops to quickly gather and integrate customer feedback.

  1. A Product Owner orders the work for a complex problem into a Product Backlog.
  2. The Scrum Team turns a selection of the work into an Increment of value during a Sprint.
  3. The Scrum Team and its stakeholders inspect the results and adjust for the next Sprint.
  4. Repeat

items.title: Kanban
items.text: Kanban is all about visualizing your work, limiting work in progress, and maximizing efficiency (or flow). Kanban teams focus on reducing the time a project takes (or user story) from start to finish. They do this by using a kanban board and continuously improving their flow of work.

items.title: Kanban Cards
items.text:
A kanban card is a visual representation of an item of work. It’s an essential component of the kanban method, a work management framework that helps visualize work, limit work in progress (WIP), and maximize efficiency (or flow). Each kanban card represents a single work item as it moves through various stages of completion which are represented on either a physical or virtual kanban board.

For agile teams, each card could encapsulate one user story. Once on the board, these visual signals help teammates and stakeholders quickly understand what the team is working on.

items.title: Work Flows
items.text: Another hallmark of the kanban board are the columns. Each column represents a specific activity that together compose a “workflow”. Cards flow through the workflow until completion. Workflows can be as simple as “To Do,” “In Progress,” “Complete,” or much more complex.

items.title: Kanban vs Scrum
items.text:
Kanban aims to give team members just enough work so the team is consistently working at capacity. Teams that practice kanban benefit from flexible planning, clearer focus, and total transparency because whatever’s on the board is the top priority. That’s what developers are working on. Kanban is great for operational teams focused on continuous delivery with changing priorities.

By contrast,sscrum divides work into a series of fixed-length iterations called sprints; whatever is scheduled for a sprint is the team’s top priority (e.g. a particular feature or group of features). Product teams with a clear roadmap and prioritized chunks of work typically benefit most from scrum.

https://www.atlassian.com/agile

items.title: How well do you know your people
items.text: Some questions to ask yourself - Do I know the personal and career aspirations of each of my team members? - Do I know why they joined the ATO and why they took their current position? - What are their strengths and areas for improvement? - Do they understand how their role affects the team and the organisation more broadly? - Are they proud of being in my team? - How do they feel about their work/life balance? - How do they prefer to give and receive feedback? - How do they prefer to receive recognition?
path: How well do you know your people

items.title: Lord of the Dance
items.text:
I danced in the morning when the world was begun, And I danced in the moon and the stars and the sun, And I came down from heaven and I danced on the earth: At Bethlehem I had my birth.

Dance, then, wherever you may be, I am the Lord of the dance, said he, And I'll lead you all, wherever you may be, And I'll lead you all in the dance, said he.

I danced for the scribe and the Pharisee, But they would not dance and they wouldn't follow me; I danced for the fishermen, for James and John; They came with me and the dance went on:

Dance, then, wherever you may be, I am the Lord of the dance, said he, And I'll lead you all, wherever you may be, And I'll lead you all in the dance, said he.

I danced on the Sabbath and I cured the lame: The holy people said it was a shame. They whipped and they stripped and they hung me on high, And they left me there on a cross to die:

Dance, then, wherever you may be, I am the Lord of the dance, said he, And I'll lead you all, wherever you may be, And I'll lead you all in the dance, said he.

I danced on a Friday when the sky turned black; It's hard to dance with the devil on your back. They buried my body and they thought I'd gone; But I am the dance, and I still go on:

Dance, then, wherever you may be, I am the Lord of the dance, said he, And I'll lead you all, wherever you may be, And I'll lead you all in the dance, said he.

They cut me down and I leapt up high; I am the life that'll never, never die. I'll live in you if you'll live in me: I am the Lord of the dance, said he.

Dance, then, wherever you may be, I am the Lord of the dance, said he, And I'll lead you all, wherever you may be, And I'll lead you all in the dance, said he.

items.title: Kindness
items.text: Adopting an attitude of kindness does not suggest that we turn a blind eye to the less-than-charitable behavior of others. It does suggest, however, that we not allow others’ lack of charity to affect our disposition. Kindness is shown through actions. When we refer to someone as being kind, it is usually in response to a gesture or action of goodness that was unmerited by the recipient. Christians are called to show kindness—to perform acts that are intrinsically good even, and especially, when those acts are unmerited and go unreciprocated. Advent Attitude 5: Kindness

items.title: Practicing Kindness Checkin
items.text:
• who is someone who has recently performed an act of kindness for you?
  • Offer a prayer of thanks for them
  • How has God shown kindness today? This week?

items.title: Radical Acceptance
items.text:
‘By refusing to accept the misery that is part of climbing out of hell, you fall back into hell.’ Marsha Leneham

Radical acceptance emphasises the importance of facing our present condition in all of its awful implications. Statements such as ‘This isn’t fair,’ ‘I don’t deserve this,’ ‘This isn’t how it’s supposed to be,’ however true, only heighten our suffering. To use a mundane example, consider being stuck in traffic, a situation where you have little control. It’s tempting to berate yourself for not leaving earlier, for living in a congested city, or to hate the person who’s causing the traffic because he didn’t check his petrol gauge before leaving home. In these moments, we can either get worked up into a frenzy over the injustice of it all – or take a deep breath and accept that it is what it is, and that it’s beyond our control.

Depression is living in the past, anxiety is living in the future, and joy is found living in the present.’

Lisa Feldman Barrett, who advises people to get into the ‘granularity’ of their emotions. If there’s something that’s making you sad, try to go even deeper in your exploration and description. Ask yourself whether it’s just sadness, or is it actually despair, grief, misery, agony, rejection, insecurity, sorrow or defeat? Is it just anger? Or is it resentment, rage, irritation, jealousy, annoyance or bitterness?

Yet, the distinction between exposure and meditation might be thin. A meditation called maranasati (death awareness) encourages individuals to frequently think about their own mortality

https://pocket.co/xhN_a9?cta=1&src=ph

items.title: Part 1, Between Nihilism and Idolatry
items.text:
• Humans are inherently religious and worshipping creatures, seeking ultimate concerns that imbue life with purpose and meaning.
  • Sinful and broken human nature leads to the co-option of the sacred to justify self-interests, nationalistic ideologies, and group superiority over others.
  • Idolatry, where God is used to legitimize personal agendas, is presented as the default and perpetual state, supported by scriptural examples.
  • The pervasive idolatry tempts many to reject religion from public life, seeking a purely secular politics based on humanistic ideals.
  • However, removing the sacred from public life leads to nihilism, characterized by a lack of meaning, purpose, and existential desolation.
  • Nihilism creates a hunger for meaning, making individuals more vulnerable to ideological radicalization and its associated temptations toward violence.
  • The Christian political witness is characterized as a navigation between idolatry (the default state of self-interested worship) and nihilism (the void created by removing the sacred). http://experimentaltheology.blogspot.com/2025/10/reflections-on-faith-and-politics-part.html

items.title: Stop Sneering and Get to Work
items.text:
Osteen is, simply, the worst. A theological embarrassment. And yet, if you are a pastor sneering at Osteen I'm pretty confident his church is larger than yours. ... Joel Osteen could speak to this gang-member and criminal, could change his life. Could you or I? And if we can't, maybe we should wipe the sneers off our faces and work at becoming better missionaries. ... Bell observed that Osteen was "parenting" people who never had any parenting, or at least not any good parenting. Many people have never experienced a stable family where they heard constant and unconditional messages of positivity, praise, and encouragement. Most people never grew up hearing "You can do this! You got this! I believe in you!" But you know who says that, over and over? Do you know who believes in you? Joel Osteen. ... Same goes for modern praise music. I can't tell you how many times I've heard seminary-educated pastors and seminary professors sneer at Christian praise music. The music is castigated for being overly individualistic, therapeutic, and sentimental. We sneer and call it "Jesus is my boyfriend" music. ... Instead of sneering at the therapeutic individualism of these songs, their focus upon me and my feelings, take a second to listen to the songs as a missionary, as a cultural anthropologist. Instead of lol lol lol how about we think for a second? To what deep ache in the modern world are these songs appealing to? ... The modern would is suffering, staring into a void of meaninglessness where something true, beautiful and good once existed. Families are broken. Depression, anxiety, suicide, loneliness and addiction at high tide. And if you look out upon all that pain, with a compassionate heart and the mind of a missionary, there really is no mystery as to why Jordan Peterson, Joel Osteen or Hillsong are so popular.

Stop Sneering and Get to Work
path: Stop Sneering and Get to Work

items.title: The Four Buddhist Mantras for Turning Fear into Love
items.text:
“When you love someone, the best thing you can offer that person is your presence.”

“Fearlessness is what love seeks,” Hannah Arendt wrote in her magnificent early work on love and how to live with fear. “Such fearlessness exists only in the complete calm that can no longer be shaken by events expected of the future… Hence the only valid tense is the present, the Now.”

We don’t need to be afraid of any of them, because transformation is always possible. Such transformation is possible only through deliberate practice — none more challenging, or more rewarding, than the practice of transforming fear into love.
path: The Four Buddhist Mantras for Turning Fear into Love

items.title: Mantra for Offering Your Presence
items.text: The most precious gift you can give to the one you love is your true presence. So the first mantra is very simple: “Dear one, I am here for you.” You’re not preoccupied with the past or the future; you are there for your beloved. You must say this with your body and with your mind at the same time, and then you will see the transformation.
path: The Four Buddhist Mantras for Turning Fear into Love

items.title: Mantra for Recognizing Your Beloved
items.text:
The second mantra is, “Darling, I know you are there, and I am so happy.”

To be there is the first step, and recognizing the presence of the other person is the second step. Because you are fully there, you recognize that the presence of your beloved is something very precious. You embrace your beloved with mindfulness, and he or she will bloom like a flower. To be loved means first of all to be recognized as existing.
path: The Four Buddhist Mantras for Turning Fear into Love

items.title: Mantra for Relieving Suffering
items.text: Even before you do anything to help, your wholehearted presence already brings some relief, because when we suffer, we have great need for presence of the person we love. If we are suffering and the person we love ignores us, we suffer more. So what you can do — right away — is to manifest your true presence to your beloved and say the mantra with all your mindfulness: “Dear one, I know you are suffering. That is why I am here for you.” And already your loved one will feel better. Recognize the presence of those who live in the same place as you, and try to be there when one of them is suffering, because your presence is so precious for this person.
path: The Four Buddhist Mantras for Turning Fear into Love

items.title: Mantra for Reaching Out to Ask for Help
items.text:
If someone else had done the same wrong to you, you would have suffered less. But this is the person you love the most, so you suffer deeply, and the last thing you feel like doing is to ask that person for help… So now it is your pride that is the obstacle to reconciliation and healing. According to the teaching of the Buddha, in true love there is no place for pride. When you are suffering like this, you must go to the person you love and ask for his or her help. That is true love. Do not let pride keep you apart. You must overcome your pride. You must always go to him or her.

The Marginalian
path: The Four Buddhist Mantras for Turning Fear into Love

items.title: Virtues are Habits we Acquire
items.text:
We want people to be more kind so we tell everyone, "Be kind." We want people to stoping stressing out so we say, "Don't worry." We want people to love more and say, "Love others." All we do is push imperatives. Do this. Be that.

Virtues are habits we acquire, not choices we make at the point of a command. Trouble is, we tend to get stuck on the commands. We tell people how they should think, feel or behave but never get around to the practices that turn these imperatives into virtues.

The Imperative to Virtue Gap
